column3:
ACK

Verified that the old code and new code produce identical blocks (calling CreateNewBlock every 100 transactions, over two weeks of data from February).
utAck -- apologies for line noise on the time thing, wasn't highly related to this.\n
The old code deliberately unlocks before calling TestBlockValidity...I'm not actually sure its worth anything, but just noting that there is actually a behavior change here.\n
Oh, oops, I thought the deliberate scoping had a purpose, but it looks like it does absolutely nothing.\n
This doesn't seem to reset at least pblock. What's the point of having a reset independent from the constructor?\n

I think that this is fine to leave as-is, but I suspect that the time should ideally be set by the client (e.g. if the block takes a long time to be found say 70 minutes than the client would have had to update their timestamp in their block).\n\nThis could cause a real problem at the halving if there is a sudden reduction in hashpower and mining time goes up past the two hour threshold and all mi
(of course this is not a correctness thing, just a potential network edge case if users improperly program against this -- I'm well aware this has been the way this code worked for a long time)\n

There is never a requirement to update the time: the constraints are:
- block.nTime >= median(block.prev^(n).nTime, n=1..11) [which never changes if no block is found to work on top of]
- block.nTime <= realtime + 120 minutes [which never goes from valid to invalid as time passes]
In any case, that's a mining protocol suggestion (ntime rolling is used in many places anyway), not something that affects the internal mining code.\n

ðŸ‘

had misread the constraints to have blocks as more time dependent.

nit: Unless there is a reason I am missing, it would be good to refactor this to use std::priority_queue like addScoreTxs for consistency. (std::priority_queue is also safer to use for preserving heap invariants)\n
nit: could be `!(blockFinished || (mi == mempool.mapTx.get<mining_score>().end() && clearedTxs.empty()))` via demorgan's which is (maybe?) a bit easier to read.\n
